qas.question: What is a tax imposed on Jews in 70 CE?
When did the FIscus Judaicus relax to exclude Christians?
Name one reason historians believe the conversion during the Roman era was limited in number and did not account for much of the Jewish population growth?

answers.text: illegality of male conversion to Judaism

qas.question: What religion was it legal to convert to in the Roman world from the mid-2nd century?
Where was it legal to convert to Judaism?
What made conversion easy in the Roman world?
When was the Fiscus Judaicus expanded to also include Christians?
What was a tax imposed on non Jewish citizens in 70 CE?

context: Other historians believe that conversion during the Roman era was limited in number and did not account for much of the Jewish population growth, due to various factors such as the <a2_0>illegality of male conversion to <b3_0>Judaism<b3_0/><a2_0/> in <b4_0>the Roman world<b4_0/> from the mid-2nd century. Another factor that would have made conversion difficult in the Roman world was <b5_0>the halakhic requirement of circumcision<b5_0/>, a requirement that proselytizing Christianity quickly dropped. <a0_0>The <b7_0>Fiscus Judaicus<b7_0/><a0_0/>, a tax imposed on Jews in 70 CE and relaxed to exclude Christians in <a1_0><b6_0>96 CE<b6_0/><a1_0/>, also limited Judaism's appeal. In addition, historians argue the very figure (4 million) that had been guessed to account for the population of Jews in the ancient Roman Empire is an error that has long been disproven and thus the assumption that conversion impacted Jewish population growth in ancient Rome on a large scale is false. The 8 million figure is also in doubt as it may refer to a census of total Roman citizens.
